head.title: USA Today to Use Items From Start-Up News Site

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: USA Today to Use Items From Start-Up News Site
hedline.hl2: USA Today to Use Items From Start-Up News Site

block.p: Three months after two journalists left The Washington Post to start a new-media venture, their political coverage has found its way back to a national newspaper: USA Today.

USA Today said Friday that it would begin using articles produced by the start-up, The Politico, a mostly online news operation staffed by journalists who have worked for news outlets like Time, The Wall Street Journal and The Associated Press.
USA Today said that it would begin using articles produced by the new-media start-up, The Politico.
Three months after two journalists left The Washington Post to start a new-media venture, their political coverage has found its way back to a national newspaper: USA Today.

USA Today said Friday that it would begin using articles produced by the start-up, The Politico, a mostly online news operation staffed by journalists who have worked for news outlets like Time, The Wall Street Journal and The Associated Press.

USAToday.com has already added a scroll box with Politico headlines on its Political News page; clicking on a headline takes a reader to the article on Politico.com. Kinsey Wilson, co-executive editor of USA Today, said that starting today The Politico would also provide at least 15 articles a week for the newspaper's Web pages, and occasionally for its printed editions.

Mr. Wilson, who used to be editor in chief of the paper's Web site, emphasized that the arrangement was not a cost-cutting effort. USA Today, published by Gannett, is the biggest paper in the country by circulation, but its newsroom is set up to put out a paper only five days a week, he said. ''We need to deepen our coverage online, where there is an expectation of 24-hour timeliness,'' he said.
If the paper's Washington reporters are worried about being upstaged by writers with bigger bylines, they are not saying; phone messages left for six of them on Friday were not returned.

Kathy Kiely, who covers Congress for USA Today, said she did not feel threatened. ''I think it's a plus for the paper,'' she said, adding, ''This is a time when a lot of publications are cutting back on their reporting resources, so the idea that we would be adding resources, even indirectly, is a wonderful thing.''

Jim VandeHei, The Politico's executive editor who founded the venture with John F. Harris, a colleague from The Post, said that the deal gave his 25 reporters a forum to reach readers ''not just inside the Beltway, but coast to coast.'' USAToday.com attracts more than nine million visitors a month, according to Nielsen/NetRatings.
